repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.unittitle: Roger M. Adelman Files of the John W. Hinckley, Jr. Trial
did.abstract: Roger M. Adelman (1941-2015) was the senior prosecutor for the United States attorney's office during the trial of John W. Hinckley, Jr. The records, ranging in date from 1981-1989, are related to this trial and Hinckley's attempted assassination of United States President Ronald Reagan in 1981. In 1982, Hinckley was found not guilty by reason of insanity. In 1984, in direct response to the Hinckley verdict, Congress passed the Comprehensive Crime Control Act, which set a higher bar for the insanity defense in federal courts.
did.physloc: Materials are stored off-site and will require additional retrieval time. Please contact the Special Collections Research Center for more information.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Paul L. Knight and Michael H. Cardozo, 2016 June 10 (Accession 2016.086)

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized in 2 series: Legal documents and Personal writings.

bioghist.head: Biographical
bioghist.p: Roger M. Adelman (1941-2015) was the federal government lawyer who led the unsuccessful prosecution of John W. Hinckley, Jr., in the 1981 assassination attempt of United States President Ronald Reagan. The trial led to significant alterations in the law regarding the insanity defense in criminal trials. Prior to 1984, defendants could be found not guilty by reason of insanity if it could be shown that, because of mental disease, they could not tell the difference between right and wrong or could not control themselves well enough to obey the law. In 1984, in direct response to the Hinckley verdict, Congress passed the Comprehensive Crime Control Act, which set a higher bar for the insanity defense in federal courts. Under this new law, lack of control was no longer a defense.

Roger M. Adelman was born on June 25, 1941, in Norristown, Pennsylvania. He earned his bachelor's degree in English at Dartmouth College in 1963 and received his law degree from the University of Pennsylvania in 1966. Adelman then went on to serve in the United States Army and attended its language school in Monterey, California, to learn Russian. After leaving the military, Adelman began working for the United States Attorney's office in Washington, DC. In 1997, the Council for Court Excellence awarded him the Justice Potter Stewart Award for his contribution to the administration of Justice in Washington. Roger Adelman died in Washington, DC, in 2015.

bioghist.head: Historical
bioghist.p: On March 30, 1981, John W. Hinckley, Jr., attempted to assassinate United States President Ronald Reagan outside of the Hilton Hotel in Washington, D.C. Hinckley wounded Regan with a bullet that ricocheted off of the presidential limousine. Hinckely also wounded Secret Service Agent Timothy McCarthy, police officer Thomas Delahanty, and press secretary James Brady. In 1982, Hinckley was found not guilty by reason of insanity and was confined to St. Elizabeths Hospital in Washington, D.C. until his release in 2016. The trial led to significant alterations in the law regarding the insanity defense in criminal trials. Prior to 1984, defendants could be found not guilty by reason of insanity if it could be shown that, because of mental disease, they could not tell the difference between right and wrong or could not control themselves well enough to obey the law. In 1984, in direct response to the Hinckley verdict, Congress passed the Comprehensive Crime Control Act, which set a higher bar for the insanity defense in federal courts. Under this new law, lack of control was no longer a defense.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Please cite unpublished materials in the following way:
Please provide the title and date of item, catalog number (if applicable it will be found written on the folder), name of the collection, name of the repository, and location of the repository.

Example: James Oglethorpe to the Trustees, 13 January 1876, RG0001 Series 1, Box 4, Folder 3. Records of the Board of Trustees, Special Collections Research Center, Gelman Library, The George Washington University, Washington, D.C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains trial transcripts, pleadings, pre-trial motions, photographs, correspondence, and personal writings. The materials date from 1981-1989. These are the records of Roger M. Adelman, who served as the senior prosecutor for the United States attorney's office during the trial of John W. Hinckley, Jr. The records are related to this trial and Hinckley's attempted assassination of United States President Ronald Reagan.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

controlaccess.subject: Insanity defense
Insanity (Law)
United States. Federal Bureau of Investigation
Legislation

did.unittitle: Legal documents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials of this series include transcripts of trial proceedings, official reports of the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), correspondence, and photographs. The series has been divided into four sub-series: Trial proceedings, Prosecutive reports, Hinckley chron file II 1982-1987, and Photographs. They range in date from 1981-1989 and include legal documents related to the trial of John W. Hinckley, Jr., in his assassination attempt of United States President Ronald Reagan.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged into 4 subseries: Trial proceedings, Prosecutive reports, Hinckley chron file II 1982-1987, and Photographs.

did.unittitle: Trial proceedings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials of this sub-series include pleadings, transcripts of trial proceedings, memoranda, motions, and depositions related to the trial of John W. Hinckley, Jr., in the attempted assassination of United States President Ronald Reagan. The items range in date from 1981-1989.

Prosecutive reports

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials of this sub-series include official reports of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, or prosecutive reports, related to the trial of John W. Hinckley, Jr., in the attempted assassination of United States President Ronald Reagan. There are 9 bound volumes, including 4 reports and 5 appendices. The materials date to 1981.

Hinckley chron file II 1982-1987

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials of this sub-series include correspondence, reports, memoranda, memos, and articles related to John W. Hinckley Jr.'s attempted assassination of United States President Ronald Reagan. The materials range in date from 1982-1987.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in the order in which it was received.

did.unittitle: Hinckley Chron File II 1982-1987 [1/3]
Hinckley Chron File II 1982-1987 II [2/3]
Hinckley Chron File II 1982-1987 [3/3]
Photographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials of this sub-series include oversized photographs that are mounted on cardboard and were likely used as trial exhibits in the case of John W. Hinckley, Jr., in the attempted assassination of United States President Ronald Reagan. The materials range in date from 1981 to 1982.

did.unittitle: Crime Scene Photographs
Crime Scene Photographs
Personal writings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials of this series include the personal writings of John W. Hinckley, Jr., as well as correspondence between Hinckley and serial killer Ted Bundy. They range in date from 1981-1986.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in the order in which it was received.
